name: European Bison
description: European bison are closely related to American bison but differ mainly in appearance. While American bison live in open landscapes with a sturdy build and massive front, European bison are forest animals, slim and laterally compressed for navigating trees.
spread_note: Originally most of Europe, east to the Volga and Caucasus, now only in protected areas of central and eastern Europe
proportions: Body length 2.5–3.5 m, tail length 60–80 cm, shoulder height 1.8–2 m, weight 350–1350 kg
reproduction: The female is pregnant for 260–270 days and gives birth to 1 calf.
attractions: European bison live in small mixed or male groups of unrelated animals, active mainly in the morning and evening when foraging.
projects_note: The last wild European bison was captured in 1921, and they were extinct in the Caucasus by 1925. Zoo breeding and reintroduction efforts have saved them.
breeding: The first bison in Prague Zoo arrived in 1932. Since 1954, breeding has been continuous, with over 90 calves born by 2014.
